en_second_half: develope. She was a woman of mean understanding, little information, and uncertain temper. When she was discontented, she fancied herself nervous. The business of her life was to get her daughters married: its solace was visiting and news.

en_results_raw: be understood. She was a woman of mean understanding, little information, and uncertain temper. When she was discontented, she fancied herself nervous. The business of her life was to get her daughters married; its solace was visiting and news. Mr. Bennet's property consisted almost entirely in an estate of two thousand a year, which, unfortunately for his daughters, was entailed, in default of heirs male, on a distant relation; and their mother's fortune, though ample for her situation in life, could but ill supply the deficiency of his. Her father had been an attorney in Meryton, and had left her four thousand pounds. The village of Longbourn was only one mile from Meryton; a most convenient distance for the young ladies, who were usually tempted thither three or four times a week, to pay their duty to their aunt and to a milliner's shop just over the way. The two youngest of the family, Catherine and Lydia, were particularly frequent in these attentions; their minds were more vacant than their sisters', and when nothing better offered, a walk to Meryton was necessary to amuse their morning hours and furnish conversation for the evening; and however bare of news the country in general might be, they always contrived to learn some from their aunt. At present, indeed, they were well supplied both with news and happiness by the recent arrival of a militia regiment in the neighbourhood; it was to remain the whole winter, and Meryton was the headquarters.

en_results_raw: screen. But I am very far from agreeing with you in your estimation of ladies in general. I cannot boast of knowing more than half a dozen, in the whole range of my acquaintance, that are really accomplished." "Nor I, I am sure," said Miss Bingley. "But they are all silly and ignorant like others." "I never saw such a woman," said Darcy. "I certainly never did. You must have had a very narrow circle, if such were all your acquaintance." "Narrow! Yes, I suppose so," said Miss Bingley, smiling. "But I have always been of the opinion that a woman may be as accomplished as any man, if she has the same opportunities and the same encouragement." "I do not know whether that is possible," said Darcy. "But I do know that a woman who is truly accomplished, is a very rare thing indeed." "I am afraid you are prejudiced," said Elizabeth, laughing. "I am not prejudiced," said Darcy. "I am only stating facts. And I must say, that I have never met a woman who was accomplished in the true sense of the word, excepting one, and she is not in this room." "Oh! Who is that?" asked Miss Bingley, with great curiosity. "A lady of great beauty and great talents," said Darcy. "But I do not think I shall ever have the pleasure of seeing her again." "I am sorry to hear that," said Elizabeth. "I should have liked to have seen her." "I daresay you would," said Darcy. "But she is not the kind of woman who would be likely to make many friends in a place like this." "Why not?" asked Elizabeth. "Because she is too proud," said Darcy. "And too clever," added Miss Bingley. "Yes, and too clever," said Darcy. "A woman who is too proud and too clever, is not likely to make many friends in a place like this." "I do not think that is a fair statement," said Elizabeth. "I think a woman who is proud and clever, is just as likely to make friends as any other woman." "I do not agree with you," said Darcy. "But I suppose we shall have to agree to differ." "Yes, I suppose so," said Elizabeth, smiling.

en_results_raw: seen them so agreeable as they were on this particular evening. They were both in high spirits, and the conversation was lively and animated, turning on various subjects, from the latest news of the neighbourhood to the merits of the different books they had been reading. Elizabeth was particularly pleased to find that they were both of the same opinion as herself on the subject of a new novel that had recently been published, and they spent some time discussing its characters and plot. As the evening wore on, they began to talk of their plans for the future, and Elizabeth was surprised to find that they were both contemplating a visit to the seaside during the summer. She had always loved the sea, and the idea of spending a few weeks by its side was extremely tempting. As they chatted, Elizabeth found herself feeling more and more at ease in the company of her friends, and she was grateful to her sister for having brought them together. The evening passed quickly and pleasantly, and when it was time to retire, Elizabeth felt that she had spent one of the most enjoyable evenings she had had for a long time.

I must confess, however, that I was not a little surprised at the contents of the letter, and I was still more astonished at the request which it contained. The writer, who signed himself 'A friend to the family,' informed me that he had been a witness to a circumstance which had occurred many years ago, and which, he believed, had a material bearing on the fortunes of my family. He stated that he had been a servant in the house of my great-uncle, and that he had seen certain documents which had been kept secret from the rest of the world. These documents, he said, were of the utmost importance, and he was willing to communicate their contents to me, provided I would meet him at a certain place, which he specified, on a certain day and hour. I must confess that I was both surprised and intrigued by this letter, and I determined to follow the instructions of the writer, and to see what information he had to communicate. I accordingly made my way to the appointed place, and there I found the man who had written the letter. He was an old man, with a kind face, and a benevolent expression, and he seemed to be deeply in earnest. He told me that he had been a faithful servant to my great-uncle, and that he had been entrusted with many secrets, which he had kept faithfully for many years. He then proceeded to tell me the story which I am about to relate, and which, I must confess, has made a deep impression on my mind.

"I did not think of her for my son," replied Mr. Bennet, "I thought of her for myself. I thought it would be a good thing for me to have a young woman in the house, to take care of me in my old age." "Oh, Mr. Bennet!" exclaimed his wife, "you are joking, I hope. You do not mean to say that you would actually marry a young woman, and bring her into this house, to take care of you?" "Why not?" said Mr. Bennet, "I am not too old to marry, and I am not too proud to be taken care of. Besides, I think it would be a very good thing for me, and for my daughters too. "But, Mr. Bennet," said his wife, "you must consider the expense. It would be a great expense to keep a young woman in the house, and to provide for her." "I do not think it would be a great expense," said Mr. Bennet, "I think it would be a very good investment. A young woman would be a great help to me, and to my daughters, and she would be a great comfort to us all." "But, Mr. Bennet," said his wife, "you must consider the propriety of the thing. But, from the observation of a very few hours, Jane's opinion of Mr. Darcy was not so favourable as at first. She found him very disagreeable, and did not like his manner of speaking and being silent; and she was convinced that he did not approve of her, and that she could not approve of him. She was not quite certain what she thought of him, but she was not inclined to like him at all. She was rather surprised, however, that he should come to Longbourn at all, and she was rather glad that he had not come to stay, for she was not at all pleased with his behaviour.

en_results: to be drawn out of our own little worlds; and, in short, we are both creatures of habit and reflection, who prefer the quiet, unobtrusive life
en_results_raw: to be drawn out of our own little worlds; and, in short, we are both creatures of habit and reflection, who prefer the quiet, unobtrusive life to the bustling, showy scenes of the world. I have often thought, indeed, that our reserve and our love of solitude were the natural consequences of our having been so much alone in our childhood, and of our having been left to the guidance of our own thoughts and fancies, without the influence of external circumstances to shape our characters and direct our tastes. But, be that as it may, I am convinced that we are both of us better suited to a quiet, domestic life, than to the excitement and turmoil of the world; and I have no doubt that we shall both find our happiness in the peaceful, uneventful existence which we have chosen.

I am not averse to being mistress of Pemberley, and I should be extremely sorry to be the means of making Mr. Darcy unhappy; but as you well know, I have always considered him the very last man in the world whom I could ever be prevailed on to marry. I am excessively fond of a cottage; there is always so much comfort, so much elegance about them. en_results_raw: of friends will involve people in troubles of this sort; and we are not to expect it. We must be serious and circumspect in our behaviour, not rash and inconsiderate, like some people we could name, who seem to think that the only way to be lively and agreeable is to be pert and meddling. We must be steady and resolute, and not suffer ourselves to be influenced by the whims and fancies of others, but act according to our own judgment and principles. This is the way to be respected and esteemed, and to maintain a good character in the world. And as for the opinion of the world, we must not be too anxious about it; we must not be afraid of what people may say, but be guided by our own sense of right and wrong, and act accordingly. This is the way to be truly happy and contented, and to enjoy a good conscience, which is the greatest blessing of all.

De repente, su hermana se detuvo y señaló un claro en el bosque, donde un grupo de flores silvestres crecían en profusión. en_results: seriously displeased, I assure you, and my displeasure was increased by the conviction that he did not admire me at all. I had heard so much of his pride, his abominable pride, that I was rather in fear of him, and I must confess
en_results_raw: seriously displeased, I assure you, and my displeasure was increased by the conviction that he did not admire me at all. I had heard so much of his pride, his abominable pride, that I was rather in fear of him, and I must confess that I was not very well pleased with him at first. His manners, though well-bred, were not such as to recommend him to a woman of sense and education, and I was not disposed to be pleased with him, even if he had been more agreeable. But, as I said, he danced only four dances, and I was not one of the four. I was very much surprised, and not a little offended, that he did not ask me to dance, and I was determined to make him feel my displeasure. I did not, however, intend to be very severe, for I knew that he was a gentleman, and I did not wish to be rude to him. I merely intended to show him that I was not pleased, and that I would not be trifled with. But, as it happened, my plan was not successful, for he did not seem to notice my displeasure, and he went on just as if nothing had happened.

Elizabeth listened attentively, and with a mixture of surprise and alarm, as her uncle went on to explain the circumstances which had led to the discovery of Mr. Bennet's imprudence. She had never suspected that her father's extravagance had been so great, or that his estate was in such a precarious state. Her uncle's words filled her with a sense of dismay and anxiety for the future, and she could not help but wonder what would become of her and her sisters if their father's affairs were not soon put in order.

When the present is secure, the future may be looked to, and even its uncertainties and dangers may be faced with equanimity. But when the present is uncertain, the future is a blank, and the mind is necessarily preoccupied with the means of securing it. It was this feeling which made Elizabeth so anxious to see her sister married, and settled for life. When her husband and Mr. Bingley were gone, Jane and Elizabeth could not help laughing at the manner in which she had been treated; and Elizabeth, who had been most concerned, was now most at ease, and even a little amused by the whole affair. "I must say, I was quite surprised," said Jane, "at the way mamma spoke to Mr. Bingley. I did not think she would have been so very civil to him." "Oh, she is always civil to strangers," replied Elizabeth; "but I think she likes Mr. Bingley very much indeed. I am sure she will be very glad to see him again." "I daresay she will," said Jane; "but I am not so sure about papa. He seemed rather surprised at Mr. Bingley's coming, and I fancy he did not much like it." "I do not think he did," said Elizabeth; "but I am sure he will be very glad to see him again, when he knows him better." Just then, the door opened, and the servant announced the arrival of the gentlemen. Mr. Bennet and Mr. Bingley came in, and the former immediately began to talk to his wife about the news of the day, while the latter went to pay his respects to the young ladies.

en_first_half: “You need not distress yourself. The moral will be perfectly fair. Lady Catherine’s unjustifiable endeavours to separate us were the means of removing all my doubts. I am not indebted for my present happiness to
en_second_half: your eager desire of expressing your gratitude. I was not in a humour to wait for an opening of yours. My aunt’s intelligence had given me hope, and I was determined at once to know everything.”
en_results: your interference, though the effect of it has been most material. I was not then master enough of myself to know what could or ought to be done; but I have since seen my own behaviour, and I will
en_results_raw: your interference, though the effect of it has been most material. I was not then master enough of myself to know what could or ought to be done; but I have since seen my own behaviour, and I will not be afraid of blaming myself. I believe I was right in not entering into explanations with you then, and I am now convinced that I was entirely justified in my own feelings and actions. My object then was to secure you, and I was willing to do so at any cost, but I have since come to see that there was a better way, a way that would have avoided all the pain and distress that we have both endured. I am now happy, truly happy, and I owe it all to the realization that our love is strong enough to overcome any obstacle, including the objections of those who would seek to tear us apart.
